justification: “The 32-item MFQ … was administered to examine participants’ endorsement of each of established moral foundations (care, fairness, authority, loyalty, and purity). Each foundation is assessed using six items…”
The same passage notes that the MFQ contains “six items” assessing fairness as one of the core moral foundations.
The description of the MFQ lists authority among the “established moral foundations” measured by dedicated items in the questionnaire.
The MFQ section includes loyalty in the set of foundations for which “each foundation is assessed using six items.”
Purity is named in the same sentence specifying the MFQ’s item clusters for each moral foundation.

measured_by: Iyer et al.’s (2012) nine-item Liberty scale
justification: “The original MFQ was accompanied by Iyer et al.’s (2012) nine items for measuring endorsement of the liberty foundation.”

measured_by: Revised Moral Foundations Questionnaire (MFQ-r) – Traditionalism factor
justification: “The first factor was labelled ‘Traditionalism’… This cluster of items… formed part of the re-analysed structure of the MFQ,” indicating that the MFQ-r factor operationalises Traditionalism.

measured_by: Revised Moral Foundations Questionnaire (MFQ-r) – Compassion factor
justification: “The second factor was labelled ‘Compassion’ and contained items such as ‘Whether or not someone cared for someone weak or vulnerable’,” showing that the MFQ-r includes a Compassion factor to measure this construct.

measured_by: Revised Moral Foundations Questionnaire (MFQ-r) – Liberty factor
justification: “The third factor was labelled ‘Liberty’ and contained items… This collection of items exclusively came from Iyer et al.’s (2012) liberty questionnaire,” specifying a Liberty factor within the MFQ-r.
Concurrent validity analyses correlated MFQ-r scores with “the ‘social change’ … OIS factors,” indicating this OIS subscale measures insecurity about social change.
The same sentence refers to the “‘systemic inequality’ OIS factors,” showing that this OIS component operationalises insecurity about systemic inequality.

measured_by: 11-point self-placement ideology scale (−5 liberal to +5 conservative)
justification: The demographic section states that participants reported “their general political views (measured using an 11-point scale anchored from −5 to +5; negative scores = liberal, positive scores = conservative).”
